Help.Text: The WEEKS() function returns the difference between two dates in weeks.The third parameter indicates the calculation mode: if the mode is 0, WEEKS() returns the maximal possible number of weeks between those days. If the mode is 1, it only returns the number of whole weeks in between.
Help.Example: WEEKS("2002-02-18"; "2002-02-26"; 0) returns 1, because there is one week and 1 day in between
WEEKS("2002-19-02"; "2002-19-02"; 1) returns 0, because there is not a whole week in between, starting at the first day of the week (monday or sunday, depending on your local settings)

Help.Text: The MONTHS() function returns the difference between two dates in months.The third parameter indicates the calculation mode: if the mode is 0, MONTHS() returns the maximal possible number of months between those days. If the mode is 1, it only returns the number of complete months in between.
Help.Example: MONTHS("2002-01-18"; "2002-02-26"; 0) returns 1, because there is 1 month and 8 days in between
MONTHS("2002-01-19"; "2002-02-26"; 1) returns 0, because there is not a whole month in between, starting at the first day of the month

Help.Text: The YEARS() function returns the difference between two dates in years. The third parameter indicates the calculation mode: if the mode is 0, YEARS() returns the maximal possible number of years between those days. If the mode is 1, it only returns whole years, starting at the 1st Jan and ending on the 31st Dec.
Help.Example: YEARS("2001-02-19"; "2002-02-26"; 0) returns 1, because there is one year and 7 days in between
YEARS("2002-02-19"; "2002-02-26"; 1) returns 0, because there is not a whole year in between, starting at the first day of the year

Help.Text: The DAYS() function returns the difference between two dates in days.
The DAYOFYEAR() function returns the number of the day in the year (1...365).
The DATE() function returns the date formatted with local parameters.
The TIME() function returns the time formatted with local parameters.
The HOURS() function returns the value of the hours in a time expression.
The function isLeapYear() returns True if the given year is leap.
The function DAYSINMONTH() returns number of days in the given year and month.
The function DAYSINYEAR() returns the number of days in the given year.
The function WEEKSINYEAR() returns the number of weeks in the given year.
The MINUTES() function returns the value of the minutes in a time expression.
The SECONDS() function returns the value of the seconds in a time expression.
The DAY() function returns the name of the day of the week (1..7). In some countries the first day of the week is Monday, while in others the first day of the week is Sunday.
Help.Example: DAY(1) returns Monday (if the week starts on Monday)

Help.Text: The MONTH() function returns the name of the month (1...12).
The CURRENTDATE() function returns the current date formatted with local parameters.
The SHORTCURRENTDATE() function returns the current date formatted with local parameters.
The CURRENTDATETIME() function returns the current date and time formatted with local parameters.
The CURRENTTIME() function returns the current time formatted with local parameters.
